thread.title: Wanted – oncologists and specialist docs who treat cancer
thread.title_full: Wanted – oncologists and specialist docs who treat cancer

author: YUEN MEIKENG
title: Wanted – oncologists and specialist docs who treat cancer
text:
Presently, there is less than half of the number needed. 
Malaysian Oncological Society president Dr Matin Mellor Abdullah said there are between 105 and 110 of such doctors in the private and public sectors. 
But with the recommended ratio of oncologists to the population being 10 to one million, Malaysia will need at least 240 of these specialists to meet that target. 
Calling it a worrying and ongoing problem, Dr Matin said the Malaysian population stood at 31 million as of Jan 1 last year. 
“Therefore, we will need to have between 240 and 300 oncologists,” he told Sunday Star . 
Dr Matin added that the country needed to look at various measures to improve the number, including inviting Malaysian oncologists working overseas to return home. 
It has been reported that there will be an expected 54% increase in the number of new cancer cases by 2025. 
Previous reports have also said that Malaysia needs at least 280 oncologists if the country was to follow a recommendation by Australian authorities to have 10 oncologists per one million people in 2010. 
Health Ministry deputy director-general Datuk Dr Jeyaindran Sinnadurai said the nation also required more radiotherapists, palliative care doctors and supporting staff to combat the scourge of cancer. 
He said efforts to build up the capacity of such medical professionals, including oncologists, would be addressed in the national cancer control plan, currently in its final stages of being drafted. 
“The task force in charge of coming up with the plan has to present it to the director-general and minister once it is finalised for their endorsement before it can be rolled out,” Dr Jeyaindran said. 
In the meantime, he said the ministry had already started promoting oncology by offering more scholarships for doctors to take up the field, aside from taking preventive measures such as providing female Form One students with free human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccines.
